He answered, "Whether one attains *ming* or not is distinguished by principle, not by examining the illusory form. One who has not attained the Dao, though living, is as if dead. One who has attained the Dao, though dead, is as if living. For what dies is the illusory form, while the Dao does not die. Yan Hui grasped Confucius’ Dao, dwelling where others could not endure its excellence, yet finding joy within it. Having gained a single goodness, he bore it with dignity and never lost it—thus he had already obtained the primordial, true, unified *qi*, returning to the root and recovering *ming*, no longer bound by yin and yang. Having reached the state of the Sage, he no longer cherished this illusory form and could die at will. This is evident in the crisis at Kuang, when he said to Confucius, ‘With you here, Hui dares not die’—sufficient proof that life and death lie with oneself, not with Heaven. As for Confucius’ remark, ‘Alas, he died young,’ this was meant to encourage his many disciples by invoking Yan Hui. If he had truly died young, how could one who had attained the Dao die prematurely? And how could one who had learned to avoid early death teach others to die young? The meaning is clear—how could it be mistaken?"

"Someone asked, 'After attaining the Dao, one’s lifespan aligns with Heaven—why then did Yan Hui die at thirty-two?' The master replied, 'After attaining the Dao, one possesses a body beyond the physical—this is called the *true body*, or the *yang spirit*. The yang spirit is the indestructible true body of vajra. Once the Dao manifests and the yang spirit emerges, one looks back upon the illusory form as a heap of dung—what is there to cling to? The sages and worthies temporarily retain the illusory body only to cultivate the true body. Once the true body is established, the illusory form serves no purpose—why not discard it?'

Another asked, 'Confucius lived over seventy years before passing—does this mean he attained the Dao more slowly than Yan Hui?' The master replied, 'Confucius was driven by a desire to save the world, seeking to spread the Dao and awaken the people. When he obtained the *lin* beast during the western hunt, he realized the Dao could not be realized in his time. Yet, unwilling to let the great Dao vanish from the world, he edited the *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents*, established the *Rites* and *Music*, expounded the *Zhouyi*, and composed the *Spring and Autumn Annals*—opening the ears of later generations and fulfilling his salvific vow. Once his heart’s work was complete, he departed this world. Yan Hui, having attained the Dao, already had Confucius preceding him in saving the world—there was no need for further effort, so he was free to transcend early.'

[Verification: Both Confucius and Yan Hui could freely master life and death, yet chose not to—this is evident in the classics. Did the master not see this? His words must serve a purpose. By strict principle: during the crisis at Kuang, Confucius trusted in Heaven, as did Yan Hui—thus they feared neither death nor life. As for Yan Hui’s early death, this was their submission to fate, not daring to defy Heaven’s decree. Hence Confucius mourned. If one claims Yan Hui dared not die while his master lived, would he have dared to die if his father lived? This affirms Yan Hui’s acceptance of fate, not the presence or absence of illusory methods. The three teachings’ core lies in *establishing ming*—precisely to align with fate. Thus, they remained unwavering in life or death, cultivating the self and awaiting destiny. The master must have understood this, yet his answer here serves a purpose. Earlier, he stated: 'The illusory has life and death, but the Dao has neither.' Later students may grasp this—yet those who study the Dao today do so with selfish motives. What more can I say? The world’s admiration lies entirely in the questions below, rooted in two great maladies: 'clinging to life' and 'craving the marvelous.' After the master’s next answer, I fear those who retreat in dismay will number far more than five thousand. Alas!]

Another asked, 'If the illusory body cannot attain the Dao, why do legends say the Yellow Emperor ascended to Heaven riding a dragon at Mount Dinghu, or that Master Xu lifted his entire household to fly away?' The master replied, 'Such events did occur, but not as commonly understood. The Great Dao of the Golden Elixir involves *taking from Kan to fill Li*, *following Kun to return to Qian*. After attaining the Dao, all yin is exhausted, transforming into the pure *Qian* body—shattering the void to become a celestial immortal of the Great Luo Heaven. This is what is meant by 'riding the dragon to Heaven,' not that the fleshly body ascended on a dragon. As for the tale of 'lifting the household to fly away,' it refers to one disciple’s attainment elevating nine generations to Heaven. Alternatively, those of great merit and conduct may receive an imperial decree from the Jade Emperor, relocating their entire family to the celestial realm of bliss to enjoy heavenly emoluments, or moving them to a grotto-heaven or blessed land to escape worldly afflictions. The uninformed assume this means flying away as immortals. Yet immortals are forged through cultivation—without practice or realization, how could one become immortal? This clarifies the meaning of 'lifting the household to fly away.' Some fools even believe houses and earthly dwellings are physically transported. Consider: immortals dwell in the realm of emptiness—how could the void bear the weight of heavy, turbid structures like timber and earth? Moreover, immortals encompass Heaven and Earth—what could they not obtain, that they would still cherish these mundane materials? Alas! Even the illusory body is discarded—why cling to earth and wood? Why not reflect deeply?'"

"[For corroboration: I once inquired of this matter with the Great Void Elder. The Elder said: 'This Dao is absolutely true—refining the real from the illusory. First, one transforms the red into white; then, the white into qi; next, the qi into primordial qi. Further refinement returns it to emptiness, uniting with the Dao, naturally reverting to the primordial. Yet this is not a matter of one day doing this, the next that—it is a single hour’s work, accomplished through daily, monthly, and yearly practice. When the Dao is perfected and the moment of ascension arrives, the body is wholly composed of congealed primordial qi, and the garments and shoes one wears are likewise transformed by qi. Thus, one may stand in sunlight without casting a shadow.

I once encountered the Mud-Pill Elder three times to inquire of this. He replied: ‘Do you still doubt the truth of reversion?’ As I pondered, he took my kerchief in one hand and lifted my hat in the other, bidding me look down. I saw only the shadow of the kerchief—nothing beyond it. Startled, I then saw him place the hat upon my head while donning the kerchief himself. Again, I perceived only my kerchief’s shadow, while my head cast no shadow of the hat.

He smiled and said: ‘Now you understand! Yet the work must begin with solid, unadorned practice to return to emptiness. Even the slightest grain of sand untransformed leaves a subtle shadow!’"]

I then recounted the inquiry regarding the ascent of one’s dwelling, to which he replied: “There are two gates to this—one of method, one of the Dao. Method is illusory; the Dao is real. Examining past and present, over seventy instances of dwelling-ascent are recorded. Yet only the Yellow Emperor, Huan Xuan, and Tao Hongjing achieved it through the Dao. Others, such as Laozi, the Prince of Huainan, and Master Jingyang, employed methods to manifest the Dao, though in truth they merely relocated to remote islands to cultivate further, refining themselves toward emptiness. Whether they attained the Dao remains unknown. These are cases where the physical body ascended with the dwelling. As for the Yellow Emperor, Huan Li, and Tao Hongjing, theirs was a bodily ascension through the heavens, while the rest—over eight hundred in number—shed their mortal forms. Yet without the endorsement of the Three Officials and a jade edict summoning them, none could ascend by chance. Can such ascension be dismissed as mere illusion? Can immortality be equated with ordinary attainment?”

Thus my master recounted, and I here append it to corroborate the records in the immortal registers. My master further stated: “The sagely achievement of dwelling-ascent begins with the practice of ‘egg-guarding.’ The secret of egg-guarding: take heaven and earth as the Dharma-body, with the great qi spiraling, encompassing the earth below and the clouds above. From afar, draw it near, practicing without cease. Once the qi of the celestial stem converges, it forms a shield around the body, impervious to wind and storm—its efficacy is then manifest. Gradually, the gate opens, and serpents and beasts cannot enter—progress deepens. With unrelenting cultivation, awaiting the appointed time, relocation becomes effortless. Yet within three thousand years, only Wei Boyang, the Ancestral Master, and Xu Xuanping, the Master of Far Wandering, have succeeded. My teacher, Li Niwan, deemed the Dao not immediately essential to oneself, so I dared not pursue it.”

He also said: “The ascent of dwellings was undertaken by ancient sages only out of necessity, as seen with the Prince of Huainan and Master Jingyang. The Prince of Huainan’s three clans ascended through the power of the Eight Lords. Master Jingyang accumulated merit through alchemy, and his disciples followed. When they incurred heavenly censure and sought to mitigate it through method, he tested them by reducing singing girls to ashes. Of over eight hundred, only Yu Zhen, Yin Zhen, and eight others upheld the three precepts. Thus, the Long Isle was elevated, while seven hundred and ninety-one could not cross, leaving behind the *Prophecy of Dragon Sands*. The precepts must be observed; let past lessons serve as warning.”

My master’s words were not without purpose, and so I record them here.

Question: “If the illusory body is of no use, why do some practitioners, after death and during burial, leave their coffins empty, or plant bamboo staffs in their stead, or leave only clothing and shoes within? Does this not mean they have taken their illusory bodies with them?”

Answer: “This cannot be generalized. Some, after attaining the Dao, shed their illusory bodies while their Dharma-bodies manifest in a certain place. Having accumulated merit and perfected conduct over decades, their work complete and virtues fulfilled, they ascend to pay homage to the Jade Emperor, concealing the celestial mechanism—appearing to die yet departing in truth. The unenlightened, finding the coffin empty, mistake this for the transmutation of the physical body into immortality. Others, though their Dao remains unfulfilled, evade calamity by employing arts of illusion, substituting staffs or garments for their forms before vanishing without trace. This, too, is not the attainment of immortality through the physical body. As the Most High said: *‘My greatest affliction is that I have a body; if I had no body, what affliction would remain?’* Thus, to shed the illusory body is to relinquish attachment.”

Question: “Yet some remain in the world without discarding their illusory forms. Why is this?”

Answer: “This, too, cannot be uniformly explained. Some, having attained the Dao but lacking sufficient merit, retain their forms to continue their work. Others have completed their *ming* (destiny) but not their *xing* (nature), and so remain bound to the illusory body. If one has perfected both *xing* and *ming*, yet clings to the illusory form despite completed merit, refusing to relinquish it, this is called a ‘home-clinging ghost’—a state immortals do not delight in.”

[Verification: Note: The “home-clinging ghost” must be an obstinate immortal who fails to comprehend the study of *xing*. Not only is their *xing* unfulfilled, but their *ming* is not the *ming* of Heaven’s mandate, relying instead on the *shen* of consciousness to solidify the illusory body. To call this the completion of *xing* and *ming* is mere worldly discourse. If, however, one’s aspiration is to achieve the Supreme Vehicle—not clinging to form but refining it into an imperceptible, illusory semblance—this is the state of *‘complete reception, complete return.’* The ancients have attained this, and such cannot be dismissed as a ‘home-clinging ghost.’ This distinction must not be overlooked.]

Someone asked, “If one completes the cultivation of *ming* yet fails to complete that of *xing*, one remains burdened by the illusory body. Why not complete *xing* first and transcend it?”

The master replied, “It depends on what one originally received from one’s teacher. If one’s understanding was thorough from beginning to end—completing *ming* and then *xing*, shedding the illusory body to emerge as the Dharma-body—this follows naturally. But some grasp only the principles of *ming* without knowing those of *xing*. They may become ‘land-bound immortals,’ attaining longevity yet unable to cast off the illusory body. If they recognize there is still a higher path, seek a teacher, and inquire into the final step—moving from effortful practice to effortless attainment—they will no longer be ensnared by the illusory body. Then, a body exists beyond the body, form and spirit both perfected, and they merge with the Dao in truth.”

Someone asked, “The effortless Way is the work of those of supreme *virtue* who preserve their form in full. Why, then, do those of lesser *virtue* who prolong life also practice the effortless Way?”

The master replied, “Those of supreme *virtue* begin with no inherent deficiency; their spiritual chamber remains open. With the true oral transmission, one resolution brings a hundredfold clarity, and they cross directly to the other shore. Thus, in practicing the effortless Way, effortful work is already contained within it—*xing* is completed, and *ming* is preserved. Those of lesser *virtue*, however, suffer from a prior depletion of prenatal *qi*, and a hundred ailments arise. Even with a teacher’s transmission, they cannot achieve immediate purity. They must progress gradually, from striving to ease, and only after completing *ming* do they converge with those of supreme *virtue* on the same path, at last attaining effortlessness. This does not mean those of supreme *virtue* practice only effortless work, nor those of lesser *virtue* only effortful work. At the ultimate height of the Dao, neither effort nor effortlessness holds; heaven and earth dissolve into emptiness. Not only is effortful work unnecessary—even effortlessness is no longer needed. The terms ‘effortful’ and ‘effortless’ refer only to the starting point of cultivation. Not only do those of supreme and lesser *virtue* differ in their approach, but men and women also begin differently in their practice.”

Someone asked, “How do men and women differ in their starting points?”

The master replied, “For men, the essential step is refining *qi*. For women, it is refining form. Refining *qi* means subduing it, ensuring it returns. When *qi* returns, emptiness deepens and stillness solidifies, root is restored and *ming* recovered, and the White Tiger descends. Refining form means concealing it, aiming for its dissolution. When form dissolves, the Four Great Elements enter emptiness, the limbs decay, and the Red Channel is severed. When the White Tiger descends in men, they revert to a youthful body, postnatal essence no longer leaks, and they can form the elixir and prolong life. When the Red Channel is severed in women, they transform into a male body, impure yin blood no longer descends, and they can escape death and enter life. Thus, men’s cultivation is called ‘Greater Yang refines *qi*,’ while women’s cultivation is called ‘Greater Yin refines form.’”

Someone asked, “Do women refining form not subdue *qi*?”

The master replied, “Women are yin by nature, so their *qi* is easily subdued. But the Red Channel poses the greatest obstacle to the Dao, and this is where they must focus their efforts. Once the Red Channel is severed, *qi* naturally becomes docile—not like men, who are yang by nature and whose *qi* is difficult to subdue. For example, while it may take a man three years to subdue *qi*, a woman can achieve it in one. If a woman possesses the resolve of a true hero and receives her teacher’s oral transmission, practicing the Greater Yin method of refining form, she can attain the Dao in three to five years—her path is even more efficient than a man’s. Yet such heroic women are exceedingly rare. They must surpass men in fortitude a hundredfold to succeed. Those equal to men in strength will never achieve it.”

“Someone asked, ‘The Great Dao makes no distinction between men and women—why then are there differences between them?’

“The master answered, ‘The Dao is the same, but its application differs. For their natures are not alike, and their physical forms are distinct. Thus, though the Dao of life and destiny remains one, its practice and effects vary greatly.’

“Someone asked, ‘How is the Red Channel severed?’

“The master answered, ‘The Red Channel arises from the body’s postnatal yin *qi*. When yin *qi* stirs, impure blood flows. To transform the blood, first refine the *qi*. Once *qi* is refined, the blood returns upward, entering the breasts, where red turns to white. Circulating throughout the body, it banishes the affliction of raging desire-fire. When desire-fire is extinguished, true fire emerges. From then on, all proceeds steadily and smoothly—preserving life and perfecting form is no longer difficult.’

“Someone asked, ‘When the golden elixir is accomplished and swallowed, does a woman transform into a man, and the old become youthful?’

“The master answered, ‘This speaks of principle, not of physical form. After a woman attains the Dao, she sheds all yin and becomes a body of pure yang—no different from a man who has attained the Dao. Thus it is said: a woman transforms into a man. After an elder attains the Dao, they return to the primordial and become a body of pure yang—no different from a child’s perfection. Thus it is said: the old become youthful. This does not mean their appearance changes.’”

Someone asked, “If the Dao has no concern with illusory appearances, why then are those with incomplete six senses not taught the Dao?”

The master answered, “Those with incomplete six senses are called the disabled and infirm—useless people. The Dao is what heaven and earth treasure, what steals yin and yang and seizes the workings of creation—this is the work of great sages. How could the disabled and infirm accomplish such earth-shaking deeds? They cannot do so not because they do not wish to, but because their form is limited and their qi obstructed. If the great Dao were entrusted to them, it would be like placing a precious treasure in a worthless place, and heaven’s punishment would surely follow. Thus, we dare not teach it. If one with incomplete six senses truly performs great deeds and cultivates great conduct, we may point them toward the lesser vehicle of nature and principle, guiding them to refine their path of coming and going. As for the great Dao of the golden elixir, we dare not teach it at all. This secret is known only to those who have heard the great Dao!”

Someone asked, “Are there not those with complete six senses who still do not grasp the principles of destiny, achieving only the cultivation of nature? Do they truly not know of the principles of destiny?”

The master answered, “The principles of destiny refer to the Dao of the nine returns, seven reversions, and the great return of golden liquid elixir—a transmission that occurs but once in ten thousand kalpas. If one is not a true man of resolve, bearing the unyielding will of vajra and the disposition of sages and worthies, they cannot attain it. Even a true teacher dare not transmit it. If they forcefully attempt to do so, spirits and gods will obstruct them in secret. This is because such a person is not a vessel capable of bearing the Dao. To transmit it to the unworthy is to leak the celestial mechanism. As for the Dao of guarding the center and embracing the One in the cultivation of nature and principle, even those of middling or lesser capacity, or those of virtuous conduct, may be guided to preserve their form. This is because the cultivation of nature and principle is an innate celestial mechanism, without the need to steal the workings of creation—it is not of great consequence. Nevertheless, it must not be recklessly transmitted to the unworthy. Generally, among learners, those of superior wisdom are few, while those of middling or lesser capacity are many. Thus, the patriarchs teach the cultivation of nature and principle to those of middling capacity and the principles of destiny to those of superior wisdom—establishing teachings according to the person. There are also teachers who transmit only the cultivation of nature, unaware of the principles of destiny, and learners who grasp only the cultivation of nature and principle, unaware of the principles of destiny. These cannot be discussed as one and the same.”

Someone asked, “If the great Dao of the golden elixir is transmitted but once in ten thousand kalpas, will it not vanish from the world?”

The master answered, “The phrase ‘once in ten thousand kalpas’ expresses its utmost reverence and preciousness, not that it is lightly transmitted. Thus, after one attains the Dao, if they do not find a suitable person, they may remain in the world for hundreds of years, waiting until they find the right one before departing. For example, Zhēnyáng transmitted to Chúnyáng, and Chúnyáng to Hǎichán and Chóngyáng—each waited hundreds of years before finding the right person. The ancients were so cautious that the prohibition against reckless transmission is self-evident. When Zǐyáng transmitted to the unworthy three times, he suffered heavenly punishment three times—this is further proof that reckless transmission must not occur.”

[Verification: After the two patriarchs, Zhōng and Lǚ, completed both nature and destiny, they remained in the world because they had not found a successor. Our tradition understands the reason for their lingering presence. The Chan school, unaware of this, mocks them as “corpse-clinging ghosts.” Thus, the actions of the noble are often misunderstood by the common. This may be appended to the discourse on lingering form for further reflection.]

Someone asked, “If the great Dao of the golden elixir is only entrusted to those of superior wisdom, must those of middling or lesser capacity forever be unable to attain it?”

The master answered, “There are those who attain it—it depends entirely on how one studies! If one treads firmly on the ground, treats it as the great matter of life, ascends from the humble to the lofty, progresses from the shallow to the profound, and persists with ever-increasing effort until bitterness turns to sweetness, a true person will surely rejoice in guiding them. But if one is inherently shallow in roots and conduct, lacking great resolve, how could they ever hear of the great Dao of the golden elixir?”

Someone asked, “Is there a method to studying the Dao?”

The master answered, “Success or failure in cultivation depends entirely on whether one’s learning ascends to the heights or remains low. Where one does not reach, one remains deluded; what one does not know, one finds difficult. Though one relies on a wise teacher for transmission, one must also awaken through personal insight. Before hearing the Dao, one must conduct oneself as one devoted to nature and destiny. One devoted to nature and destiny is unburdened by wine, lust, wealth, or temper; greed, anger, delusion, and attachment are all cast aside. Apart from the Dao, they have no other concerns. With sincere heart and true intent, they draw near to those of the Dao, revering them as they would heaven, earth, and the gods, without the slightest deceit. They further cultivate bitter resolve and establish virtue, striving to accumulate merit. They do not cease until they attain understanding, and even if they spend their entire life without attaining it, they do not regret it. With such a mindset, sages and worthies will secretly guide them, and true teachers will gladly instruct them.

Nowadays, people do not study the Dao with sincerity. Even the intelligent refuse to humble themselves; if they do humble themselves, after a few days, they demand the Dao. At the slightest dissatisfaction, they assume they lack affinity and promptly depart. Throughout their lives, they do not accumulate virtue or establish conduct, but instead fixate on clothing and food, entangle themselves in worldly affairs, vie for superiority, indulge in greed, anger, delusion, and attachment—nothing is lacking. If they chance upon some minor side practice, they treasure it as if it were the greatest jewel, becoming self-satisfied and complacent. Even if a superior person stands before them, they pride themselves on their own attainment and refuse to seek correction. With such deceit in their hearts, how could they ever attain the true Dao?

A true person, when they first emerge, is already different from others. They possess both resolve and the ability to learn, are both honest and wise, and refuse to waste time or squander their future. After the Dao illuminates their heart and they see their nature, they know there is still more to be done. They must seek out enlightened teachers, and ultimately receive the transmission of the Apricot Grove, thereby completing the great Dao. Lǚ Dòngbīn failed three times in refining the elixir, but after obtaining Master Cuī’s *Mirror for Absorbing the Medicine*, his great elixir was finally accomplished.”

Those two masters both maintained empty minds and thus reaped the benefits of receptivity. Later learners, however, are arrogant in heart and overbearing in qi, claiming sagely wisdom and self-sufficiency. Unwilling to work earnestly for their nature and life, they indulge in empty posturing, yet still vainly aspire to immortality. This is not seeking fortune but inviting misfortune—how foolish indeed!

**[Reference Note: Here follows the account of how Lǚ Dòngbīn, through Master Cuī’s *Mirror for Absorbing the Medicine*, finally accomplished the returning elixir. Profound indeed! Profound! Such matters may be spoken of to those who understand, but are difficult to convey to the vulgar. If one merely treats this as a public case and reads the text repeatedly without grasping its essence, they will scarcely avoid plunging into water or fire, courting self-destruction. Even if one grasps the essence but lacks an empty mind—remaining arrogant and self-sufficient—they will still miss the opportunity before them, returning empty-handed from a mountain of treasure. The fault lies in their unwillingness to work earnestly for their nature and life, instead indulging in empty posturing.

This "empty posturing" refers to the "head" within the boundless body of my Dao—one of the Three Powers and the Eight Lords. Suspended at the summit of Mount Sumeru, what lies beneath this head is known to be taken as medicine, placed behind the mirror, and refined before it. Thus, one neither errs by attachment nor falls into emptiness. Swallowing it, one ingests it—this is called attainment, this is called completion. This is the public case of how Lǚ Dòngbīn, by refining Master Cuī’s *Mirror for Absorbing the Medicine*, finally accomplished the elixir.

I recall my teacher, the Venerable Tàixū, once expounded this profound meaning, yet he also spoke of a deeper mystery: when the mysterious pass opens wide, worldly wealth is exhausted. If one obtains this treasure without proper preparation, one may still face the peril of plunging into water or fire.

Thus, I append this answer to corroborate the earlier response of Wùyuán, for it was not without oral transmission. The later answer, however, was perhaps too profound to be openly revealed.]

Someone asked: “If Lǚ Dòngbīn failed three times in refining the returning elixir, was it because what he obtained was not genuine?”

The answer: “Lǚ Dòngbīn’s Dao came from the Perfected Lord of True Yang—utterly true, a thousand times true. How could it not be genuine enough to return? The issue was that after returning, he still lost it! In the practice of the golden elixir, one must know the maturity of the medicine when gathering it, know moderation when refining it, know auspicious and inauspicious signs when congealing the elixir, know addition and subtraction when nurturing it, and know the proper timing when releasing it. Moreover, there is the authenticity of the medicine, the measure of the dosage, and the sequence of its application—whether forward or reverse. There are countless intricate details, where the slightest deviation leads to a vast error. Lǚ Dòngbīn’s three failures in refining the returning elixir must have been due to subtle miscalculations in the firing times, some oversight in the finer points, causing him to miss the opportunity before him, obtaining it only to lose it again.

Thus, those who study the Dao must thoroughly understand the beginning and the end, penetrate the subtle and master the wondrous, harbor no doubts whatsoever, and only then may they proceed. Only then will they not err when tending the furnace.”

“[Verification: Now, considering the above: Lü Zu, being a sage, must have penetrated the subtle and mastered the wondrous—how could he have erred in the firing times’ subtleties? His oversight must have been in the earlier transmission of the method, specifically the lack of Master Cui’s *Mirror of Entering the Medicine*. Within this mirror, the primordial qi fails to coalesce at the center, and the postnatal does not thereby transform. This is also called merely toying with emptiness. Without true yin to aid it, true water and true fire do not meet, the substance does not transmute—how then could it gather and be preserved for oneself? Lü Zu’s failure stemmed from this.

Having obtained the text, one grasps its meaning from its title and employs it in refinement, thereby achieving coagulation. Lü Zu, who began with purity and stillness, naturally attained Master Cui’s *Mirror of Entering the Medicine*. Using it to toy with emptiness, emptiness itself wholly returns, yet the principle of purity and stillness remains unlost—profound, is it not? Profound indeed!

The marvel of the text’s title is thus: Wu Yuanzi understood this but dared not expound it to disciples. Here, he merely answers and hints with the four characters ‘harbor no doubts whatsoever,’ speaking thus to those of like mind among his disciples. The careless disclosure of the Great Dao is like this.]”

“Someone asked, ‘If one thoroughly penetrates the beginning and end and sets to cultivation, can one then attain the Dao?’

The master replied, ‘A master craftsman teaches others the compass and square but cannot impart skill. What a teacher transmits is no more than pointing out the true medicine and true fire, the great pass and great aperture. As for the subtlety of their application, the urgency or slowness of their practice, and the swiftness or delay of their fruition—these depend on the student’s strength, the keenness or dullness of their resolve, and the sharpness or bluntness of their nature-root. Thus, the methods of practicing the Great Dao comprise three approaches—upper, middle, and lower—each to be followed according to one’s capacity.’

Someone asked, ‘What are these three methods?’

The master replied, ‘The upper method is the method of spontaneity. The middle method is the method of expedience. The lower method is the method of grinding and polishing.

The method of spontaneity is sudden awakening and perfect penetration, where one resolution settles all; bare and pure, naked and free, perfectly rounded, radiantly luminous—whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, one never departs from this. Like a bright mirror or still water, nothing is not reflected, and nothing can deceive it. One moves with ease along the central Way, practicing it naturally—this is the union of heaven and humanity.

The method of expedience is returning from the postnatal to the prenatal, proceeding along the Dao while practicing counter to it. One transforms the false with the true and borrows the false to perfect the true. Adapting to circumstances and responding to conditions, one acts expediently, with inner and outer mutually relying upon each other.’”

The method of grinding and polishing is for those of dull nature and limited insight. They must apply effort to the ground of the heart, wholly abandoning worldly affairs. They harden their resolve, weary their sinews and bones, starve their bodies, enduring a thousand trials and a hundred refinements. They cling firmly to what is good, suffering what others cannot suffer, enduring what others cannot endure. What others achieve once, they achieve a hundred times; what others achieve ten times, they achieve a thousand. Through every hardship and affliction, they forge ahead with relentless effort, until suddenly their original face is revealed. From there, they proceed with steadfast and solid practice, converging with the upper and middle methods on the same track. This is the path of strenuous effort, seeking the Way through one’s own exertions.

These three methods are all secret teachings passed down orally by the immortals and perfected ones of old, instructing people to act according to their capacity. Those who cannot practice the upper method may practice the middle; those who cannot practice the middle may practice the lower. All ultimately aim at the completion of nature and life. Beyond these three, there are no other methods.

[Verification: It is said that even if the Most High were to return, these words could not be altered. Yet all begin with the practice of refining the heart, within which the preservation of life is contained. Through this single answer, the master’s merit is truly great! In the study of nature, if one’s practice of life reaches this level, it must be of the middle or upper grade. From here, one may advance to study Cui’s *Mirror of Entering the Elixir*—one who refines thus will surely succeed, let alone those of the middle or upper capacity. As for us, we can only follow the lower method. Alas! Scholars must recognize that even one of Qiu’s caliber began with the lower method—how much more so for those whose capacity falls far short of Qiu’s?

I heard this from my late teacher, Master Taixu. He said: “Master Qiu was the Great One Descended to the Mortal Realm, yet he endured seventy-two great trials and countless small ones—freezing to death, starving to death, even being trampled to death, none of which were counted among the lesser trials. He accepted them all with equanimity and was ultimately selected by the Golden Gate as an immortal, ascending to the rank of Celestial Minister, becoming the teacher of ten thousand generations. The Fifth Patriarch was enfeoffed as an Imperial Lord, and even Master Liu was granted an imperial title. Who are we, that we should dare find the lower method too arduous?”]

My late teacher further recounted: “When Master Qiu’s Dao was perfected and he was summoned to the Celestial Gate, he was so overcome with grief that he could not rise. Master Lü memorialized: ‘Qiu, though descended as the Great One, endured such trials—how much more so for mortals of shallow capacity, who cannot withstand such refinement? If none can endure, the transmission of the Dao will be broken.’ This moved the Jade Emperor to console him: ‘Should mortals possess even a third of your resolve, their attainment will equal yours. The celestial immortals of the upper realms, though unanticipated, will bow in reverence as if their crowns were shattered.’ Master Qiu then expressed his gratitude and withdrew.”

This episode is recorded in the Daoist Canon—a great fortune for later learners—yet one must not cling to it for self-comfort. My late teacher, in recounting this, never allowed himself such ease, so profound was his warning to later disciples. Thus, I record it here to admonish myself.

---

Someone asked: “I have heard there are five ranks of immortals. Do they all follow the same Way?”

I answered: “They do not. The Way of the Celestial Immortals refines the Ninefold Return and Sevenfold Reversion into the Golden Elixir, completing both life and nature, forging an indestructible vajra-body, and manifesting a hundred million transformations, hidden or revealed beyond measure. This is the Way transmitted once in ten thousand kalpas.

The Way of the Earthly Immortals reverses the postnatal to restore the prenatal, returning to non-being and recovering the root to revive life, condensing spirit and gathering qi to preserve form and prolong existence—achieving undying longevity.

The Way of the Ranked Immortals involves receiving the talismans of the Three Bureaus and refining the wondrous methods of the Three Caverns of Highest Clarity, enabling flight through clouds and mist, evading the Three Calamities and Eight Difficulties, and moving without obstruction. This is the Way of the Southern Palace’s protective arts.

The Way of the Ghostly Immortals cultivates the emptiness of true nature, exhausting the past and foreseeing the future, exiting through the yin-spirit in *shijie*, avoiding evil destinies. This is the Way of preserving form through the Dao.

The Way of the Incipient Immortals subdues body and mind, nurtures essence and qi, prolongs life without suffering—this is the Way of cultivating the postnatal.

Of these five ranks, only the Earthly Immortal, by advancing one step further and practicing the Way of Non-Action, may ascend to the rank of Celestial Immortal. The others are all subject to kalpic reckoning; to attain the rank of Celestial Immortal, many barriers remain. Without the alchemy of the Golden Elixir to transmute them, success is nearly impossible.”

---

[Corroboration: I heard my late teacher, Master Taixu, say: “Those who refine the generative substance of the Supreme Ultimate as their sacred embryo attain the rank of Celestial Immortal. Those who refine the generative substance of Heaven-and-Earth as their sacred embryo attain the rank of Earthly Immortal. Those who refine the primordial true yin and true yang of the Void as their sacred embryo attain the rank of Divine Immortal. Those who refine the generative substance of the living dragon and lively tiger in the Void as their embryo attain the rank of Human Immortal. If one further knows how to draw in the One of the Supreme Ultimate to transmute it, this is the Water Immortal—unpredictable in transformation, slightly inferior to the Celestial Immortal, and not merely indestructible.”]

---

Someone asked: “To become a sage, an immortal, or a buddha—are these not all called ‘attaining the Dao’?”

Someone asked: “Why is it called the Golden Elixir, and why is it also called the Ninefold Return, Sevenfold Reversion, Golden Liquid, Great Return Elixir? Why speak not of the Dao but of the Elixir?”

The master replied: “The Dao is the primordial undifferentiated qi, what is called the Supreme Ultimate. The Elixir is perfect and unblemished, lively and free, an image of the Supreme Ultimate. The Elixir is the Dao, the Dao is the Elixir—their names are two, but their principle is one. Gold is a substance that endures through ancient and modern times without decay, coeval with Heaven and Earth; we take it for its firmness. Nine is the complete number of metal; seven is the complete number of fire—both belong to yang. ‘Return’ and ‘reversion’ mean restoring to the state of pure yang without yin. The Dao is fundamentally non-action, yet the method requires action. Because of its non-action, the transformations of yin and yang cannot be without loss. The sage employs the method of cultivation: refining with metal and fire. This can restore what is deficient to wholeness and ensure that what is whole remains eternally unblemished. It returns to the Supreme Ultimate, returns to the Ultimateless, and reaches the state of no sound, no scent, the realm of profound stillness. Heaven and Earth may perish, but this does not perish—hence it is called the Ninefold Return, Sevenfold Reversion, Golden Liquid, Great Return Elixir. It is called the Elixir because it is named for the process of refinement through fire.”

Someone asked: “In cultivating this Great Elixir, is it better to practice in activity or in stillness?”

The master replied: “The Dao pervades waking and sleeping, reaches the hidden and the manifest, unbound by movement or stillness. As for the great cultivator, lively and free, outwardly rounded and inwardly square—why not dwell in the marketplace or serve at court?”

Someone asked: “In the marketplace or at court, one cannot avoid human sentiments and worldly affairs. How can one focus wholeheartedly on cultivating the Dao?”

The master replied: “Precisely in the marketplace and at court is the place to exert great function and activate great mechanism—this is the highest level of practice. The Golden Elixir exists within humanity and is sought within the marketplace and court. The ancients, dwelling in bustling capitals, relied on those with power to accomplish this—this is the very point! ”

Someone asked: “The Dao is in the Void, yet also in humanity, in the marketplace and court—why is this?”

The master replied: “Because it is in the Void, the common people use it daily without knowing. If they knew it, whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, all would be the Dao. Humanity is the proper place for cultivation; the marketplace and court are the best places for action. How could it be that only in stillness, with the body at rest and all dharmas empty, is the Dao level?”

Someone asked: “If walking, standing, sitting, and lying down are all the Dao, why is there also the practice of refining sleep?”

The master replied: “Refining sleep is a matter for beginners. When ordinary people sleep, their spirit enters the cavern of yin, and their qi disperses to the four limbs. In dreams, they are upside-down, falling into nets, cauldrons, pits, and traps without exception. What is accumulated during the day is not equal to what is depleted at night. Therefore, one must temper the demon of sleep, causing the heart-spirit to reside in its chamber, the clear qi to ascend, and the turbid qi to descend—only then can the Dao be practiced without obstruction. The ancient immortals said: ‘Sleeping for an hour is dying for an hour. Sleeping for a day is dying for a day. With daily progress, one thousand days without sleep will suffice.’ They also said: ‘One year without sleep, the lower elixir forms; two years without sleep, the middle elixir forms; three years without sleep, the upper elixir forms.’ This is certain speech. If in emptiness, light is born, and spirit-illumination is constant, then even in sleep one remains awake—there is no harm in sleeping. The *Cantong Qi* says: ‘In sleep, the spirit embraces the gods; upon waking, one awaits the signs of life and death.’ This is not sleep that harms the work. Until one reaches this state, one must not sleep. The elder Zhang of Guoqing in Shu, and Zhang of Huangzhong—the Sleeping Immortals—both began by refining sleep and later achieved prolonged sleep. This is the proof of refining sleep.”

Someone asked: “Are there three elixirs: the upper, middle, and lower elixir?”

Answer: “It is all one elixir, but spoken of in parts. The lower elixir refines essence into qi. The middle elixir refines qi into spirit. The upper elixir refines spirit to return to emptiness. The three elixirs are named according to their stages. When one reaches the stage of returning to emptiness, essence, qi, and spirit merge into one qi—this is the Great Return Elixir of Golden Liquor. The scriptures’ teachings on the ‘three fields’ and ‘three passes’ refer to this.

[Verification: Now, elixir methods do not mean refining essence today, qi tomorrow, and spirit the next day. Rather, all three methods are present within a single moment. Just as in a single elixir text, though the stages from beginning to end are many, one does not practice one stage today and another tomorrow. All stages are traversed within a single moment without omission, thus avoiding the risk of imbalance. Yet this is far beyond what those who have not opened the passes can achieve.

The passes consist of the three front and three rear passes. Opening the passes regulates the Conception and Governor Vessels. The three front passes regulate the Conception Vessel, while the three rear passes regulate the Governor Vessel. Only when the Conception Vessel is open can the Governor Vessel be regulated. In principle, this is so, but in practice, it is not. Rather, one regulates them directly through inhalation and exhalation.

During inhalation, qi is drawn from the Yin Heel Point at the perineum. From this point, it ascends in reverse, passing through the tailbone and spine, crossing the occiput to reach the crown, and entering the Heavenly Valley. The crown is Kunlun—man’s head. The Heavenly Valley is the center of the human brain, the upper elixir field. From the brain, it descends through the nose to the upper lip, where it meets the Conception Vessel at the Flower Pool. The Flower Pool is beneath the tongue, and the philtrum is its location—this is the established method for regulating the Governor Vessel.

Exhalation begins at the Flower Pool, following the path through the Jade Pillow (the chest) and reaching the Central Yellow (the middle elixir field). From there, it descends to the abdomen, settling in the deep region behind the navel, called the Sea of Qi—the lower elixir field. From there, it reaches the Yin Heel Point, located before the anus and behind the scrotum, where the Conception and Governor Vessels intersect—this is the established method for entering the Conception Vessel.

All this is achieved by guiding qi with intention, aligning thought with the Dao. This is the established method beginners must use to open the passes. As Ancestor Lü said: ‘When the three threes are open, half the work is done; when spirit opens them, the gentle wind is at rest.’ The gentle wind refers to nasal breathing. When the heart is utterly still and breath becomes so subtle it seems closed, this is the method of fetal breathing. When the Dao reaches fetal breathing, it is the spiritual achievement after the three threes are open—it is not a separate spiritual attainment.

At first, students must rely on guiding breath through inhalation and exhalation with intention. Once the passes are open and the three fields are unobstructed, as practice deepens into extreme emptiness and profound stillness, this fetal breathing naturally dissolves, becoming true breathing. Breath here means cessation. When practice attains true cessation, breathing ceases, all meridians stop, the six bowels and five viscera settle into perfect harmony, and the primordial qi is gathered from this stage.

Students must understand that ‘cessation’ and ‘breath’ refer to the utmost subtlety, where one is unaware of beginning or end. This is the qi circulating throughout the body. All the fine stages of elixir texts are encompassed within this single moment, circulating without omission. The great function of elixir texts—seizing the transformations of creation—must not be underestimated. Practicing thus daily without interruption, one will surely attain the rank of Heavenly Immortal, let alone lesser achievements.

The essentials lie in ‘two transformations,’ ‘one return,’ and ‘two unions.’ Now, step by step, returning again and again, daily progress may seem insufficient, but monthly progress is more than enough. The *Book of Changes* says: ‘Not far—return.’ It also says: ‘If one does not constantly maintain virtue, disgrace may follow.’ The practice is alive and fluid, depending on the individual. Let students take heed.]”

Someone asked, “Are essence, qi, and spirit postcelestial or precelesetial?”

The master replied, “They are precelesetial. The *Heart Seal Scripture* says: ‘The three superior medicines are spirit, qi, and essence; dimly discerned, faintly perceived; invisible to sight, inaudible to hearing; from Nonbeing guard Being, and in an instant they are accomplished.’ How could they be regarded as postcelestial, tangible things? Thus, the great practitioner refines precelesetial primordial essence, and the essence of intercourse naturally does not leak; refines precelesetial primordial qi, and the qi of breathing and exhaling naturally harmonizes; refines precelesetial spirit, and the spirit of thought and emptiness naturally attains stillness. When the precelesetial is accomplished, the postcelestial is transformed. Let students diligently cultivate and practice, and only then will they see results. Otherwise, even the postcelestial cannot be preserved—how much less the precelesetial?”

---

Someone asked, “If it is said to be accomplished in an instant, why then speak of refining essence into qi, refining qi into spirit, and refining spirit to return to emptiness?”

The master replied, “Accomplishment in an instant is the effect of obtaining the medicine. Refining essence, refining qi, and refining spirit are the gradual work of cultivation and the subtleties of the firing process.”

---

Someone asked, “The three superior medicines all belong to the precelesetial—is the Golden Elixir formed from these three?”

The master replied, “Though the three medicines belong to the precelesetial, they are formless and imageless, still belonging to yin, and cannot congeal the sacred embryo. Only when transformed by the precelesetial True One qi of emptiness and nonbeing can the formless generate form, the insubstantial generate substance, and the three medicines become purely yang!”

---

Someone asked, “If the formless generates form and the insubstantial generates substance, does the sacred embryo then have an appearance?”

The master replied, “It is a dharma-body, not a material form. The dharma-body is form yet not form. For this single qi congeals from emptiness and nonbeing, and is also called the yang spirit. When this spirit gathers, it takes form; when it scatters, it becomes qi. It enters water yet does not drown, enters fire yet is not burned; tigers and rhinoceroses cannot harm it, blades cannot strike it.”

“It moves freely without obstruction, unlike the corporeal body burdened by great suffering.”

Someone asked, “What of those who release the yin spirit?”

The master replied, “That is the Jade Fluid Returned Elixir. Those who fully realize the true suchness of their nature—once true suchness is realized, the will remains undivided, and thus congeals into spirit. Over time, when stillness reaches its utmost, the spirit departs, traversing a thousand miles in an instant, perceiving the distant and knowing the future. Yet this is but a ghost-immortal, without shadow or form. Should one desire form, one must undergo rebirth, seeking out the enlightened in the next life to cultivate the Great Elixir of Golden Fluid and thereby attain it. Thus, the great cultivator, having completed the Jade Fluid Returned Elixir, proceeds to refine the Great Elixir of Golden Fluid, aspiring to reach the state of pure yang without yin and nothing more.”

[Verification: I once heard my late master, Tai Xu, say, “Even those who have attained ghost-immortality but have not shed the physical body—though they know of the supreme Mahayana—may still seek the Great Elixir of Golden Fluid through a swift method. They must empty and still the body and mind, extinguish sensory awareness, block perception and hearing, and cut off all thoughts, returning to the state of an infant before it can cry. With single-minded sincerity, they must welcome the True One of the Limitless, and the Great Elixir of Golden Fluid will naturally be swiftly obtained. Then, as if awakening from a dream, they will spontaneously ignite the true fire, neither martial nor literary, refining and nurturing it. One day, when yin is transformed into pure yang, the way of celestial immortality may be learned. Yet one must beforehand regard existence and nonexistence with indifference, remain unshaken by alarm, unmoved by joy, and beyond all this, view everything as dream, illusion, bubble, or shadow. Only then can the True One remain constant, and the postnatal be transformed by the primordial.

This primordial is the ‘cause,’ meaning dependence—dependence on the True One bestowed by the Limitless. This bestowed One is the mother of the Golden Fluid, capable of illuminating the body. The yin of the body is the Three Treasures within us: in the body, it is the prenatal; at its extreme, it is the postnatal—still a yin entity, transformed only by dependence on the One. Yet at this stage, the power of discernment in the body must inevitably diminish; one must not grow lazy. Initially, one may feel unable to sustain it, but gradually, one returns to the original state, entering ever greater peace. The limbs grow stronger, the complexion radiant, the eyes luminous. Then, by aligning with the celestial pivot and reflecting the True One within, one’s own True One is daily renewed. With unwavering devotion, how could one fail to fully restore the primordial unity and even see worldly wealth overflow? When the time is ripe, the Great Return Elixir descends, and one need never fear sinking into water or entering fire.” He also said, “If a ghost-immortal, having attained the Dao, does not add further practices, when calamity strikes and the four elements are no longer one’s own, with no refuge to rely on and no desire to transmigrate, how can one open a new path?”

My late master left this discourse, which I have carefully appended here to supplement what Wu Yuanzi did not address. Scholars may use it for verification.]

Someone asked, “Are those who seize wombs, usurp bodies, or return to old dwellings this yin spirit?”

The master replied, “No. The yin spirit of true suchness is the primordial spirit. It is called yin only because one has not fully realized the mandate. As for those who seize wombs or usurp bodies, they merely manipulate the consciousness-spirit, clinging to the seeds of samsara, utterly unrelated to the Great Dao. Thus, they pass from one existence to another, endlessly cycling through birth and death. Their only difference from ordinary people is that they cannot choose their dwelling place and do not enter other species. How could they ever achieve the clarity of mind, realization of nature, or the ability to enter samadhi and release the spirit?”

Someone asked, “If one has realized nature but not the mandate, will one be deluded in the next life?”

The master replied, “Some will be deluded, others not. Those not deluded are born with innate knowledge of the principles of nature and seek the Great Elixir to complete the Great Dao. The deluded lose their former path and require the guidance of an enlightened teacher to awaken to past causes. Consider the Ming dynasty’s top scholar, the Perfected Luo—had his father not reminded him, he might have nearly forgotten! Though deluded, he still possessed karmic roots, so a single reminder sufficed to awaken him. Without such roots, no reminder could rouse him. This applies not only to those who have realized nature but also to those of earnest aspiration who study the Dao their entire lives without encountering an enlightened teacher. After death, they are reborn with karmic roots. As soon as they emerge, they know of this great matter and remain within the Dao, refining it through myriad methods, single-mindedly devoted to cultivation, indifferent to glory, wealth, and nobility. All such people possess karmic roots. Without them, even if one is orphaned, impoverished, or faces a hundred hardships, one would rather endure suffering to the end than enter this path.”

Someone asked, “Those who cultivate nature must return to the human world to complete the Great Dao. Those who cultivate the mandate attain a lifespan equal to heaven’s—surely they do not return?”

The master replied, “Some do return. The arts of extending life are not attainable by those who are not true great men, nor practicable by those who are not of heaven-endowed supreme wisdom. Even if one attains them, one must also possess deep ancestral virtue, great personal merit, and countless celestial affinities converging to proceed without hindrance, smoothly and sequentially, to complete this great task. If one’s ancestors lack virtue, or one’s own karmic roots are shallow, though one may forge ahead boldly, the mandate may expire before the task is done.”

“Or one may be hindered just as one’s merit begins to take effect, and demonic obstacles arrive prematurely. Often there are those who possess the method but lack the resources, who grasp the Dao but lack the strength, and many perish while still embracing the Way. Though they may not have completed the Dao, their comings and goings are clearly distinct from those of ordinary people. Some die after achieving half their merit, others before reaching halfway. Those who die after half their merit is done will surely be born with innate knowledge in their next life. Those who die before reaching halfway will surely be born with the resolve to pursue the Dao. Thus, those who study the Dao must recognize their own karmic roots and not abandon themselves in despair—for once one loses the human form, it is difficult to regain for ten thousand kalpas.”

Someone asked, “Those born with knowledge—can they cultivate without seeking a teacher and succeed on their own?”

The master replied, “Though they possess innate understanding, they still have points of confusion. Without encountering an enlightened teacher to guide them, they will not attain the Dao. If they meet such guidance, they will suddenly awaken to perfect comprehension, resolving all doubts at once. From there, their practice will unfailingly lead to completion. I have encountered two such born-knowing individuals: one was Master Gu of Jiangsu, the other Master Wang of Longxi. Master Gu was deluded by his official career, Master Wang by the pursuit of wealth. Though they knew the Way, they did not value their nature and life—this was the source of their confusion. Such individuals must surely lack great ancestral virtue and personal merit, which is why they remain entangled, unable to escape the net. Who knows what their next life will bring? How lamentable!

Later learners, should you not cultivate virtue early?”

“A disciple asked, ‘Does this disciple possess past-life roots?’

The master replied, ‘Without past-life roots, how could you have heard the name of the Great Dao? How could you have heard the teachings of the Great Dao? Whether you possess past-life roots or not, you yourself do not know. I have a few words for you—you will know for yourself.’

Then he spoke a gatha:
*In a former life, your surname was Yuan,
In this life, your surname is Lu.
Yuan was named Chengde,
Lu is named Wogu.
This is the cause and effect between past and present—
Examine your steps carefully.
The meaning is quite clear—
Awaken early, you must awaken early.*

At these words, the disciple suddenly awakened. Kneeling, he offered a song:
*Having awakened to past and future lives,
Others are myself, and I am others.
Breaking open the chaos to enter the numinous cave,
I see at last that original, singular truth.
This singular truth is like dew or lightning—
No head, no tail, no face.
Pillar of heaven, pillar of earth, beyond thought,
In the dim and distant, transformation arises.
Fortunately, the kind teacher secretly revealed it,
So I recognize this ancient treasure.
The true countenance is right before my eyes—
Why labor elsewhere to establish practice?’*

Between master and disciple, in their exchange of questions and answers, they unknowingly saw the eastern sky brighten and the earth suffused with light. The disciples dispersed to attend to their duties. Master Wuyuan then strolled alone to the Pavilion of Cleansing the Heart.”

The Purple Clarity Elder states:
“That essence is not the essence of intercourse—
it is the saliva in the Jade Emperor’s mouth.
That qi is not the qi of breath—
know instead it is the mist of primordial simplicity.
That spirit is not the spirit of thought—
it may stand shoulder to shoulder with the Primordial Beginning.”

These are what is called primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit. To call essence, qi, and spirit "primordial" is to speak of the things that are originally so. Before this body existed, these things already were; only afterward did the formless give rise to form, the insubstantial give rise to substance. They come from the time before father and mother united. At the moment of union, when the father’s essence has not yet been released and the mother’s blood has not yet enclosed, when emotions merge and intentions align, within that dim and distant state there is something—barriers secretly dissolve, and all becomes one, an undispersed cloud of mist. Then, as essence is discharged and blood receives it, essence and blood fuse, enclosing this single truth, transforming and taking shape. Already, essence, qi, and spirit reside within the form. Though called three, they are in truth one. "One" refers to the meaning of the primordial undifferentiated; "three" refers to the division of the numinous. One is the substance; three are the functions. For the primordial undifferentiated substance is pure and unadulterated as essence, flows through the blood vessels as qi, and is empty and lively as spirit. Three yet one, one yet three.

The so-called "three grades of superior medicine" are the functions; the so-called "complete and perfect" is the substance. One cannot speak only of three, nor only of one. Many learners do not understand that three are one and one are three. Some cling to the primordial and guard the one, falling into attachment to emptiness; others refine the three grades of medicine, losing themselves in attachment to form. Attachment to emptiness or form—neither is the wondrous principle of returning to the origin. To return to the origin is to return to primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit.

If one wishes to cultivate the Dao, one must first know that these three things lie hidden within the primordial undifferentiated. Separated from the primordial undifferentiated, they are no longer the original substance of primordial essence, qi, and spirit; losing this original substance, they are no longer the primordial things.

The *Heart Seal Scripture* says:
“The three grades of superior medicine—
spirit, qi, and essence.
Dimly, faintly, obscurely, profoundly,
seen yet unseen,
heard yet unheard...”

"From nonbeing guard being, and in an instant it is accomplished."

Called "dimly, faintly," called "obscurely, profoundly," called "being and nonbeing"—this reveals it as a formless thing. Only this primordial essence is like a pearl, like dew, pure and unadulterated, moistening the hundred bones; primordial qi is like smoke, like mist, threading through the hundred vessels; primordial spirit is most numinous, most sagely, governing all affairs. Knowing this, one may prolong life and extend years, attaining ageless longevity. If the cultivator can recognize these three medicines, then the cultivation of the Dao holds promise.

[Verification: If the cultivator can from the primordial undifferentiated embody and recognize the Three Treasures, they will not err. Moreover, the compassionate instruction of "moistening" and the like reveals the meaning of "nonbeing that is not nonbeing"—as clear as words on the palm, sufficient for realization. Having attained it, guard it, and one will not fall into attachment to emptiness. If one can reflect on the "from nonbeing" secret, one will not fall into attachment to form. The essential words of the ancient sages rely entirely on spiritual apprehension; hearing but not understanding is enough to lead one astray. If after reading this passage one still clings to form or emptiness, what more can I do!]

Postnatal essence, qi, and spirit.

Postnatal essence is the essence of intercourse. Postnatal qi is the qi of respiration. Postnatal spirit is the spirit of thought. These three are tangible and manifest, things that arise only after the body’s birth.

When male and female unite, essence and blood merge to form the embryo. Within the womb, there is only primordial qi, and no qi of respiration. When the ten months of gestation are complete and the child emerges from the womb, at the moment of birth, with a cry, it receives the tangible qi of Heaven and Earth, which enters the cinnabar field and unites with the primordial qi. From then on, qi moves in and out through the mouth and nose, externally connecting with the qi of Heaven and Earth—this is the root of respiratory qi.

Postnatal spirit also arises at this moment; this spirit is the consciousness that transmigrates through kalpas. It arrives first at birth and departs first at death. Whether one becomes human or beast, whether one does good or evil—it is this. Whether one is born or dies—it is this. Moving from this to that, shifting from old to new, there is nothing that is not this.

At the very moment of the newborn’s cry upon touching the earth, this spirit enters its aperture—thus, if an infant does not cry at birth, it cannot speak, for no spirit has entered its aperture. At the time of birth, spirit and qi govern one another, forming the root of the postnatal and the basis for the growth of the illusory body. As for the essence of sexual union, it is entirely a product of later existence. While in the womb, there is no such essence; even at birth, the body possesses none. Only when one reaches the age of sixteen, with primordial yang qi at its fullest, does it inevitably overflow and, having reached its peak, return. When yang reaches its extreme, yin arises; as yin arises, yang wanes. Yin qi takes charge, and yang qi retreats. The formless yin then generates the tangible yin: the aperture in the kidneys opens, true water diminishes, and the fire of desire subtly arises. With the slightest stimulation, this fire flares upward, steaming the entire body, stirring the blood and vessels of the hundred bones, and boiling the fluids of the five viscera and six bowels. All surges upward to gather at the Baihui acupoint atop the head—this point being where the hundred vessels converge. From here, qi and blood descend along the spine to the Shenshu acupoint, where they first transform into a white substance, then pass through the Weilu to reach the yin aperture and finally discharge. This essence did not exist at birth, nor even afterward—it is merely the transformation of qi and blood! The kidney aperture is but the gate through which essence exits; how could essence ever reside in the kidneys? The so-called essence of sexual union arises only through union and sensation; without union or sensation, there is no essence. Even nocturnal emissions occur due to sensation; if they happen without sensation, it is because the kidneys are weak and the blood vessels unstable, with pathogenic fire driving the essence out. This is the origin of the essence of sexual union.

When yang reaches its extreme and yin arises, not only does essence come into being, but thoughts and deliberations also emerge, and the breath of respiration becomes coarse. Scholars must recognize that these three—essence, thought, and breath—are all products of existence after birth, not of existence before birth. If one relies on things that arise after birth to preserve life, prolong years, and transcend yin and yang, is this possible? Scholars should ponder this deeply.

[Verification: It is noted that the ancients cherished these three substances of the body, for if one can return them, the three may revert to the One, and what was later becomes no longer later. In essence, the method lies in nothing more than "returning to the nonexistent."]

**Primordial True Unity of Qi**
Yuan Duzi said: “The primordial qi comes from the midst of emptiness and nothingness.”
*The Awakening to Reality* states: “The Dao, from emptiness and nothingness, generates the One qi; from this One qi, yin and yang are produced.”
The *Daoguang* says: “There is a thing prior to Heaven and Earth, nameless and originally quiescent. It can be the master of the myriad forms, yet does not fade with the four seasons.”
All these speak of primordial qi as the ancestral qi of living things, arising from emptiness and nothingness, the master of the myriad forms and the origin of Heaven and Earth. It is formless and imageless, soundless and odorless—unseen to the eye, unheard to the ear, and untouchable by the hand. Yet though formless, it can generate form; though imageless, it can generate images. In terms of its spirit, it is the spirit beyond spirits; in terms of its qi, it is the true unity of qi; in terms of its essence, it is the true unity of essence, also called the true seed, the golden elixir, or the immortal formula of another house. It cannot be compared to the qi of postnatal respiration, the spirit of deliberation, or the essence of sexual union, nor is it the same as primordial essence, primordial qi, or primordial spirit. For primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit, when in the postnatal realm, are yang, but when returning to the primordial, they become yin. Unlike the primordial true unity of qi, which remains indestructible through ten thousand kalpas, transcends all beings, and stands alone in honor—unbound by life and death, unconstrained by existence and nonexistence—it is the root of postnatal essence, qi, and spirit, and the sovereign of primordial essence, qi, and spirit. It is the most yang of things, the treasure of Heaven, yet few recognize it.

This thing is neither within nor without, neither bound by the five aggregates nor the eight consciousnesses, neither in the five viscera nor the six bowels, neither at the gates of the six senses nor in the hundred bones and apertures. It resides solely in the mysterious pass, the one aperture. If one seeks it with intention, one clings to form; if one guards it without intention, one clings to emptiness. It cannot be grasped by thought or discussed in words. It has always existed, yet when yang gives rise to yin, it flees to another house and is no longer ours. The perfected person employs methods to pursue and gather it, making the substantial insubstantial and the tangible intangible. Stirred, it takes form, coming from the midst of emptiness.

To refine and cultivate it, one employs the yin tally and yang fire to forge the elixir, coalescing it into a single grain as small as a millet seed. Swallowing and ingesting it, one ignites the treasure of the primordial, transforming non-being into being; transmutes the acquired into the innate, turning yin into yang. The Three Corpses and Five Thieves vanish without trace; the eighty-four thousand hair-spirit deities all become protectors of the Dao. Thus it is said: *"A single grain of golden elixir swallowed into the belly—only then does one know one’s fate is not ruled by Heaven."*

The deluded do not recognize this primordial True Unity of qi as the ancestral qi that gives life to all things, the primal qi before the separation of the Great Vagueness, the numinous root at the dawn of chaos. Some mistake *yuan* qi for the primordial True Unity; others take the qi of breathing in the cinnabar field as the primordial True Unity; still others regard embracing oneness and guarding the center as preserving the primordial True Unity, or seeing emptiness and stilling thoughts as observing the primordial True Unity. Then there are those hell-bound seeds who refine the five metals and eight minerals, or gather red lead and plum blossoms, believing these to be the ingestion of the primordial True Unity. How could such myriad divergent paths ever speak of the primordial True Unity?

The primordial True Unity of qi is the primordial ancestral qi that gives birth to Heaven, Earth, and all beings. Vast beyond all bounds, minute beyond all measure; in movement and stillness it is undivided, in yin and yang it is perfectly blended. In the primordial, it gives rise to yin and yang; in the acquired, it conceals itself within yin and yang. It is the true One, not the false one. To embrace and guard the true One—how could the true One be embraced or guarded? If it could be embraced or guarded, it would not be the true One, and what one embraces or guards would surely be the false one. To observe and still the true One—how could the true One be observed or stilled? If it could be observed or stilled, it would not be the true One, and what one observes or stills would surely be the false.

As for the thousand gates and ten thousand doors of the various heterodox schools, all mistake the thief for the son, abandon the correct to follow the perverse, and do not know what the true Unity of qi truly is. No wonder they reach old age without accomplishment and fall into emptiness and ruin!

When Wu Yuan first encountered the old man of Kan Valley, he was shown the great Dao of cultivating reality, with all matters made clear. Only the phrase *"the primordial qi comes from the midst of emptiness"* remained obscure to him, eluding his vision for thirteen years. He pored over elixir scriptures but never grasped its essence. Later, he met the Immortal Liu Zhangren, who pierced the source and origin, cracked open the iron pellet, and spoke with such clarity that all became luminous in his heart. Only then did he realize that true emptiness is truly empty, and the true One is truly one—not possessed by oneself, nor obtained from another; beyond words or images, grasped only through intention, apprehended only through spirit. Released, it pervades the six directions; gathered, it retreats into secrecy. It penetrates Heaven and Earth, enabling one to become a sage or a worthy, to attain immortality or buddhahood—all arising from this.

If one knows this primordial True Unity of qi, the great foundation is established, and all else is but secondary. Thus the ancient immortals said: *"Obtain the One, and all things are complete."*

---

**Verification:** With the proper method of cultivation, every step becomes the Dao. The ancient immortals said: *"Wherever green willows grow, one may tether a horse; every household’s gate opens onto Chang’an."* To seek the true One, one must practice sincerely and attain realization naturally—without profound cultivation, there is no chance of success. For the Dao expounded by Wu Yuan is the primordial great Dao, purely concerned with returning to the origin. If one does not place body and mind prior to the primordial, the mysterious pass will not open.

Thus, according to Wu Yuan’s revealed practice: without natural attainment, the primordial does not manifest, and what one obtains is not genuine. Only by embracing, guarding, observing, and stilling—beginning the work prior to the primordial and deeply cultivating the natural state—does one’s entire spirit verify the One. Seeking the One through the One is as easy as turning a hand. How could there be the flaw of mistaking the false for the true?

Based on what I have heard and this exposition, the essential warnings are against the two schools of *"red lead and plum blossoms"* and *"five metals and eight minerals."* The ancient sages practiced these methods only as catalytic agents, for they possess profound and wondrous functions. If used for ingestion, they are not the methods of the divine immortals and must be firmly rejected. Beyond these two, every other school may lead to fruition, but all must proceed from non-being as the principle. In the sequence of non-being, one must follow the order of internal observation, external observation, and distant observation. Only when one attains emptiness beyond emptiness, stillness beyond stillness, may one advance to seek the sagely Dao, shatter the void, and become non-dual and non-separate from the primordial True Unity of the void. This is the way to obtain the primordial True Unity of qi—a teaching I received from the Primordial Void Master and verified with the True Man of Jizu Mountain, offered here to supplement what Master Wu Yuan did not expound.

---

**The True and False Body and Mind**
People today speak only of body and mind, knowing only the illusory body and mind while unaware of the true body and mind. Abandoning the true to follow the false, no wonder their lifespan is not yet exhausted, yet body and mind are already weary, their form like that of the living while their soul enters the ghostly cavern!

Why is this so? The illusory body is the fleshly body; the illusory mind is the human mind. The eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and intention all arise from the illusory body. Joy, anger, sorrow, joy, love, aversion, and desire all arise from the human mind. At the gates of the six senses, every encounter can destroy life. The seven emotions and deluded thoughts, each and every one, can lead to death. A bump or a collision, and they erupt. How many escape without harm to life and destiny? To regard the illusory body and mind as real is to take the thief as one’s son and the servant as one’s master. When Heaven does not grant more years, where will the body be?

Where does the heart reside? Without doubt, it is an illusory thing. As for the true body, it is the Dharma-body. The true heart is the Heavenly Heart. Yin and yang, the Five Phases—all arise from the Dharma-body. Infant boy, maiden girl, Wood Mother, Metal Duke, Yellow Dame, coral, giant clam, crystal, jade, gold—all are born of the Heavenly Heart. The five natures and causes are all seeds of Dao-attainment. The five supreme treasures are all resources for elixir-refinement. Gather them, cultivate them, and one may raise the dead, restore youth, and reverse aging.

Yet most do not recognize this Dharma-body and Heavenly Heart. Thus, the Dharma-body lies buried while the illusory body acts; the Heavenly Heart retreats while the human heart rules. Therefore, birth after birth, death after death, the wheel of rebirth turns endlessly, without cessation. Now, this Dharma-body supports heaven above and props up the earth below. It has no head, no tail, no back, no front, standing upright without leaning. In its hardness, it shatters empty space; in its softness, the ten thousand transformations all cease. In its firmness, it enters water without drowning, enters fire without burning, passes through metal and stone unimpeded. Tiger spells cannot harm it, blades and weapons cannot strike it—here lies the abode of life. This Heavenly Heart is neither defiled nor pure, utterly empty yet utterly numinous. Still and unmoving, it responds when stirred. In stillness, it is soundless and odorless; in motion, it is supremely divine and wondrous. In form and image, it is like a crescent moon, like an upturned bowl, like a millet grain—neither form nor emptiness, yet both form and emptiness; neither being nor non-being, yet both being and non-being—here lies the abode of nature.

Know this body and heart, and cultivate nature and life—then completing nature and life becomes as easy as turning one’s palm.
